cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
During the 1970s which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The question asks for a car maker that produced both the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS during the 1970s.
2. The Triumph TR7 was introduced in 1975 and is known as a product of the Triumph brand, which was part of the British Leyland Motor Corporation during that time.
3. The Jaguar XJS was launched in 1975 as well and is associated with the Jaguar brand, which was also under the British Leyland umbrella during the 1970s.
4. Both cars were produced by the same parent company, British Leyland, which was a major automotive manufacturer in the UK during that era.

Answer:
British Leyland.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
During the 1970s which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Triumph TR7 is a sports car which was manufactured from September 1974 to October 1981 by the Specialist Division (latterly the "Jaguar-Rover-Triumph" division) of British Leyland in the United Kingdom. It was initially produced at the Speke, Liverpool factory, moving to Canley, Coventry in 1978 and then finally to the Rover Solihull plant in 1980. The car was launched in the United States in January 1975, with its UK home market debut in May 1976. The UK launch was delayed at least twice because of high demand for the vehicle in the US, with final sales of new TR7s continuing into 1982.\n', "TWR Jaguar cars won the WSCC outright in 1987, 1988 and 1991 and won the prestigious 24 Hours of Le Mans and the 24 Hours of Daytona in 1988 and 1990. The series started in 1985 with XJR-6 (Group 44 used XJR-5 and XJR-7), designed by Tony Southgate, with a chassis built from carbon-fibre and power provided by a highly tuned Jaguar V12 engine. This was followed by XJR-8, which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1987, then XJR-9 which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1988 and also secured victory at Le Mans the same year, returning in much the same form as the XJR-12 to win Le Mans again in 1990. TWR developed its own engine for the next series of cars, the XJR-10 (for IMSA) and XJR-11 (for WSCC) of 1989 and 1990, a V6 turbo-charged 3.5 litre, which was capable of far more power than the V12 but was less suited to 24 hour racing (hence the XJR-12 being deployed at Le Mans and the 24 hours of Daytona).\n", 'The Jaguar XJ-S (later called XJS) is a luxury grand tourer manufactured and marketed by British automobile manufacturer Jaguar from 1975 to 1996, in coupé, fixed-profile and full convertible body styles. There were three distinct iterations, with a final production total of 115,413 units over 20 years and seven months.\n', 'In November 1944 what was left of the Triumph Motor Company and the Triumph trade name were bought by the Standard Motor Company and a subsidiary "Triumph Motor Company (1945) Limited" was formed with production transferred to Standard\'s factory at Canley, on the outskirts of Coventry. Triumph\'s new owners had been supplying engines to Jaguar and its predecessor company since 1938. After an argument between Standard-Triumph Managing Director, Sir John Black, and William Lyons, the creator and owner of Jaguar, Black\'s objective in acquiring the rights to the name and the remnants of the bankrupt Triumph business was to build a car to compete with the soon to be launched post-war Jaguars.\n', 'The Triumph TR7 Sprint version of the Triumph TR7 sports car was produced by the Triumph Motor Company (part of British Leyland) in 1977 in very limited numbers: probably no more than 61 in total. It used the 127\xa0bhp, 16-valve, 2-litre version of the Triumph slant-four engine from the Triumph Dolomite Sprint, a highly tuned version of which, "rated at 225\xa0bhp at 8000\xa0rpm" by 1977, was used in the Group 4 TR7 cars of the BL works rally team, from 1976 until 1978. This was instead of the TR7 base model\'s 105\xa0bhp, 8-valve, 2-litre version of the same basic slant-4 engine. The 16-valve version was originally specified in the Dolomite Sprint at 135\xa0bhp, and carefully assembled, standard engines had been known to give a sustained 150\xa0bhp on the factory test bed.\n', 'The Triumph TR6 (1968–76) is a sports car built by British Triumph Motor Company between 1968 and 1976. It was the best-seller of the TR range when production ended, a record subsequently surpassed by the TR7. Of the 91,850 TR6s produced, 83,480 were exported; only 8,370 were sold in the UK.\n', 'Because of proposed US legislation on roll-over protection at the time of its launch, the TR7 was not initially available as a convertible. In early 1979, Triumph belatedly introduced a convertible version, called the TR7 Drophead Coupé (DHC), which first went on sale in the US (the original hardtop model being known as the Fixedhead Coupé, or FHC). A small number of pre-production cars were manufactured at Speke in 1978, soon after the pre-production TR7 V8 (later designated TR8) and TR7 Sprint cars. The British market received it in early 1980. The prototype for the convertible version of the original Harris Mann design came from Michelotti and the engineering to make it work was done by Triumph.\n', "In 1982, a successful relationship with Tom Walkinshaw's TWR team commenced with the XJ-S competing in the European Touring Car Championship, which it won in 1984. In 1985, the TWR XJ-S won the Bathurst 1000 race. In the mid-1980s TWR started designing and preparing Jaguar V12-engined Group C cars for World Sports Prototype Championship races. The team started winning regularly from 1987, and won Le Mans in 1988 and 1990 with the XJR series sports cars. The Jaguar XJR-14 was the last of the XJRs to win, taking the 1991 World Sportscar Championship.\n", "TWR created 'TWR Sport' in 1984 to produce heavily modified versions of the Jaguar XJ-S. Designated XJR-S, the cars benefited from the racing experience in European Touring Cars, featuring improved aerodynamics; uprated suspension and brakes; tuned engine and detail changes. The success of TWR Sport led to the formalising of a joint venture (50/50) in 1988 called 'Jaguar Sport'. Jaguar Sport would initially focus on building tuned versions of Jaguar road cars (the XJR-S coupe and XJR saloon). However, with overwhelming demand to put the concept Jaguar XJ220 into production, it was decided that Jaguar Sport would design and develop the new supercar, for which a new facility was secured at Bloxham, Oxfordshire. Production commenced in 1990 with the final cars delivered in 1993.\n", 'The Triumph TR4 is a sports car produced by the Triumph Motor Company from 1961 to 1965. Code named "Zest" during development, it was the successor to the TR3A. The car was based on the chassis and drivetrain of the previous TR sports cars, but with a modern body designed by Michelotti. As 40,253 cars were built during its production years it proved to be very successful.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question regarding which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS during the 1970s, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content:
1. **Triumph TR7 Production**:
   - The Triumph TR7 was manufactured by the Specialist Division of British Leyland in the United Kingdom from September 1974 to October 1981. 
   - It was initially produced at the Speke factory and later moved to Canley and then to the Rover Solihull plant.
   - The car was launched in the US in January 1975 and in the UK in May 1976.

2. **Jaguar XJS Production**:
   - The Jaguar XJ-S (later called XJS) was manufactured and marketed by British automobile manufacturer Jaguar from 1975 to 1996.

3. **Company Background**:
   - British Leyland was a significant automotive manufacturer in the UK during the 1970s, known for producing several brands, including Triumph.
   - Jaguar was a separate entity but was also part of the British automotive landscape during this time.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:
- **Identification of Manufacturer**: The passages clearly indicate that both the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS were produced by companies associated with British Leyland. This is crucial for answering the question, as it identifies the overarching corporate structure under which both vehicles were produced.
  
- **Historical Context**: Understanding the timeline of production (1974-1981 for the TR7 and 1975-1996 for the XJS) provides context for the question, confirming that both cars were indeed produced during the 1970s.

- **Brand Recognition**: The mention of the Triumph and Jaguar brands helps in recognizing their significance in the automotive industry during that era, which may not be familiar to all readers.

- **Manufacturing Locations**: The details about the production locations (Speke, Canley, Rover Solihull) provide insight into the manufacturing capabilities and geographical context of British Leyland, which can be relevant for understanding the logistics and historical significance of car production in the UK.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides essential background knowledge about the manufacturers of the Triumph TR7 and Jaguar XJS, their production timelines, and the corporate structure of British Leyland. This information is vital for accurately answering the question and understanding the historical context of these vehicles in the automotive industry during the 1970s. The model can now confidently conclude that both cars were produced by British Leyland, with Triumph and Jaguar being the respective brands involved.

To answer the question regarding which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS during the 1970s, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages.

1. **Triumph TR7**: 
   - The Triumph TR7 was manufactured by the Specialist Division of British Leyland, which later became known as the "Jaguar-Rover-Triumph" division. The TR7 was produced from September 1974 to October 1981, indicating that it was indeed manufactured during the 1970s. The car was initially produced at the Speke factory in Liverpool and later moved to Canley, Coventry, and then to the Rover Solihull plant. The TR7 was launched in the US in January 1975 and had its UK debut in May 1976, highlighting its significance in the market during that decade.

2. **Jaguar XJS**:
   - The Jaguar XJS (initially called XJ-S) was manufactured by Jaguar from 1975 to 1996. This luxury grand tourer was produced in various body styles and had a production total of 115,413 units over its lifespan. The XJS was introduced in the same year as the TR7, further establishing the timeline of production for both vehicles during the 1970s.

3. **Contextual Relationship**:
   - Both the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS were produced by British automotive manufacturers that were part of British Leyland. The TR7 was produced under the Specialist Division of British Leyland, while the Jaguar XJS was produced by Jaguar, which was also under the British Leyland umbrella during that period. This connection indicates that both vehicles were part of the same corporate structure, reflecting the automotive landscape of the UK in the 1970s.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - The 1970s were a transformative period for British car manufacturers, marked by the consolidation of various brands under British Leyland. This context is crucial as it explains the shared corporate lineage of the Triumph and Jaguar brands, which produced these iconic models during a time of significant change and competition in the automotive industry.

### Summary:
The Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS were both produced by British Leyland during the 1970s. The TR7 was manufactured by the Specialist Division of British Leyland from 1974 to 1981, while the Jaguar XJS was produced by Jaguar from 1975 to 1996. Both vehicles reflect the automotive heritage of the UK during this era and are emblematic of the brands' efforts to compete in the sports and luxury car markets. The relationship between the two models underlines the interconnectedness of British automotive manufacturers during a pivotal time in their history. Thus, the answer to the question is that both the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS were produced by British Leyland.

", 'The Jaguar XJ-S (later called XJS) is a luxury grand tourer manufactured and marketed by British automobile manufacturer Jaguar from 1975 to 1996, in coupé, fixed-profile and full convertible body styles. There were three distinct iterations, with a final production total of 115,413 units over 20 years and seven months.
', 'In November 1944 what was left of the Triumph Motor Company and the Triumph trade name were bought by the Standard Motor Company and a subsidiary "Triumph Motor Company (1945) Limited" was formed with production transferred to Standard's factory at Canley, on the outskirts of Coventry. Triumph's new owners had been supplying engines to Jaguar and its predecessor company since 1938. After an argument between Standard-Triumph Managing Director, Sir John Black, and William Lyons, the creator and owner of Jaguar, Black's objective in acquiring the rights to the name and the remnants of the bankrupt Triumph business was to build a car to compete with the soon to be launched post-war Jaguars.
', 'The Triumph TR7 Sprint version of the Triumph TR7 sports car was produced by the Triumph Motor Company (part of British Leyland) in 1977 in very limited numbers: probably no more than 61 in total. It used the 127\xa0bhp, 16-valve, 2-litre version of the Triumph slant-four engine from the Triumph Dolomite Sprint, a highly tuned version of which, "rated at 225\xa0bhp at 8000\xa0rpm" by 1977, was used in the Group 4 TR7 cars of the BL works rally team, from 1976 until 1978. This was instead of the TR7 base model's 105\xa0bhp, 8-valve, 2-litre version of the same basic slant-4 engine. The 16-valve version was originally specified in the Dolomite Sprint at 135\xa0bhp, and carefully assembled, standard engines had been known to give a sustained 150\xa0bhp on the factory test bed.
', 'The Triumph TR6 (1968–76) is a sports car built by British Triumph Motor Company between 1968 and 1976. It was the best-seller of the TR range when production ended, a record subsequently surpassed by the TR7. Of the 91,850 TR6s produced, 83,480 were exported; only 8,370 were sold in the UK.
', 'Because of proposed US legislation on roll-over protection at the time of its launch, the TR7 was not initially available as a convertible. In early 1979, Triumph belatedly introduced a convertible version, called the TR7 Drophead Coupé (DHC), which first went on sale in the US (the original hardtop model being known as the Fixedhead Coupé, or FHC). A small number of pre-production cars were manufactured at Speke in 1978, soon after the pre-production TR7 V8 (later designated TR8) and TR7 Sprint cars. The British market received it in early 1980. The prototype for the convertible version of the original Harris Mann design came from Michelotti and the engineering to make it work was done by Triumph.
', "In 1982, a successful relationship with Tom Walkinshaw's TWR team commenced with the XJ-S competing in the European Touring Car Championship, which it won in 1984. In 1985, the TWR XJ-S won the Bathurst 1000 race. In the mid-1980s TWR started designing and preparing Jaguar V12-engined Group C cars for World Sports Prototype Championship races. The team started winning regularly from 1987, and won Le Mans in 1988 and 1990 with the XJR series sports cars. The Jaguar XJR-14 was the last of the XJRs to win, taking the 1991 World Sportscar Championship.
", "TWR created 'TWR Sport' in 1984 to produce heavily modified versions of the Jaguar XJ-S. Designated XJR-S, the cars benefited from the racing experience in European Touring Cars, featuring improved aerodynamics; uprated suspension and brakes; tuned engine and detail changes. The success of TWR Sport led to the formalising of a joint venture (50/50) in 1988 called 'Jaguar Sport'. Jaguar Sport would initially focus on building tuned versions of Jaguar road cars (the XJR-S coupe and XJR saloon). However, with overwhelming demand to put the concept Jaguar XJ220 into production, it was decided that Jaguar Sport would design and develop the new supercar, for which a new facility was secured at Bloxham, Oxfordshire. Production commenced in 1990 with the final cars delivered in 1993.
", 'The Triumph TR4 is a sports car produced by the Triumph Motor Company from 1961 to 1965. Code named "Zest" during development, it was the successor to the TR3A. The car was based on the chassis and drivetrain of the previous TR sports cars, but with a modern body designed by Michelotti. As 40,253 cars were built during its production years it proved to be very successful.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS, focusing on their production, ownership, and historical context. Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Extracted Information:

1. **Manufacturers and Ownership**:
   - The Triumph TR7 was manufactured by the Specialist Division of British Leyland, which included the "Jaguar-Rover-Triumph" division. This indicates that Triumph was part of a larger automotive group during its production.
   - The Jaguar XJS was manufactured by Jaguar, a British automobile manufacturer, from 1975 to 1996.

2. **Production Timeline**:
   - The Triumph TR7 was produced from September 1974 to October 1981, with its UK launch in May 1976.
   - The Jaguar XJS was produced from 1975 to 1996, indicating that both cars were contemporaneously produced during the late 1970s.

3. **Historical Context**:
   - The Triumph brand was acquired by the Standard Motor Company in 1944, which had been supplying engines to Jaguar since 1938. This historical relationship between the two brands may suggest a shared engineering heritage and potential collaboration.
   - The Triumph TR7 was initially produced at the Speke factory and later moved to Canley and Solihull, indicating a shift in production facilities that could reflect changes in manufacturing strategies or company restructuring.

4. **Market Positioning**:
   - The Triumph TR7 was marketed as a sports car, while the Jaguar XJS was positioned as a luxury grand tourer. This distinction highlights the different target markets and branding strategies employed by the two manufacturers.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Relationships**:
   - By recognizing that both cars were produced by companies under the same corporate umbrella (British Leyland), the model can infer potential synergies in design, engineering, and marketing strategies. This understanding can enhance the model's ability to draw connections between different entities and their historical contexts.

2. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - The overlapping production timelines of the TR7 and XJS allow the model to reason about market competition, consumer preferences, and the evolution of automotive technology during the 1970s. This temporal aspect can improve the model's ability to analyze trends and make predictions based on historical data.

3. **Causal Relationships**:
   - The historical acquisition of Triumph by Standard Motor Company and its relationship with Jaguar provides a causal framework for understanding how corporate decisions impact product development and market positioning. This can help the model infer how past events shape current realities in the automotive industry.

4. **Market Dynamics**:
   - The distinction between the sports car and luxury grand tourer segments can inform the model about consumer behavior and preferences, enabling it to make more nuanced inferences about market dynamics and product strategies.

### Conclusion:

The extracted information provides a rich context for understanding the relationships between the Triumph TR7 and Jaguar XJS, their manufacturers, and the broader automotive landscape of the 1970s. By integrating this knowledge, the model can enhance its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to better analyze historical events, recognize patterns, and make informed predictions about similar scenarios in the future.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
During the 1970s which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS?
answer:
Reasoning process:
1. The question asks for a car maker that produced both the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS during the 1970s.
2. The Triumph TR7 was introduced in 1975 and is known as a product of the Triumph brand, which was part of the British Leyland Motor Corporation during that time.
3. The Jaguar XJS was launched in 1975 as well and is associated with the Jaguar brand, which was also under the British Leyland umbrella during the 1970s.
4. Both cars were produced by the same parent company, British Leyland, which was a major automotive manufacturer in the UK during that era.

Answer:
British Leyland.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
During the 1970s which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Triumph TR7 is a sports car which was manufactured from September 1974 to October 1981 by the Specialist Division (latterly the "Jaguar-Rover-Triumph" division) of British Leyland in the United Kingdom. It was initially produced at the Speke, Liverpool factory, moving to Canley, Coventry in 1978 and then finally to the Rover Solihull plant in 1980. The car was launched in the United States in January 1975, with its UK home market debut in May 1976. The UK launch was delayed at least twice because of high demand for the vehicle in the US, with final sales of new TR7s continuing into 1982.\n', "TWR Jaguar cars won the WSCC outright in 1987, 1988 and 1991 and won the prestigious 24 Hours of Le Mans and the 24 Hours of Daytona in 1988 and 1990. The series started in 1985 with XJR-6 (Group 44 used XJR-5 and XJR-7), designed by Tony Southgate, with a chassis built from carbon-fibre and power provided by a highly tuned Jaguar V12 engine. This was followed by XJR-8, which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1987, then XJR-9 which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1988 and also secured victory at Le Mans the same year, returning in much the same form as the XJR-12 to win Le Mans again in 1990. TWR developed its own engine for the next series of cars, the XJR-10 (for IMSA) and XJR-11 (for WSCC) of 1989 and 1990, a V6 turbo-charged 3.5 litre, which was capable of far more power than the V12 but was less suited to 24 hour racing (hence the XJR-12 being deployed at Le Mans and the 24 hours of Daytona).\n", 'The Jaguar XJ-S (later called XJS) is a luxury grand tourer manufactured and marketed by British automobile manufacturer Jaguar from 1975 to 1996, in coupé, fixed-profile and full convertible body styles. There were three distinct iterations, with a final production total of 115,413 units over 20 years and seven months.\n', 'In November 1944 what was left of the Triumph Motor Company and the Triumph trade name were bought by the Standard Motor Company and a subsidiary "Triumph Motor Company (1945) Limited" was formed with production transferred to Standard\'s factory at Canley, on the outskirts of Coventry. Triumph\'s new owners had been supplying engines to Jaguar and its predecessor company since 1938. After an argument between Standard-Triumph Managing Director, Sir John Black, and William Lyons, the creator and owner of Jaguar, Black\'s objective in acquiring the rights to the name and the remnants of the bankrupt Triumph business was to build a car to compete with the soon to be launched post-war Jaguars.\n', 'The Triumph TR7 Sprint version of the Triumph TR7 sports car was produced by the Triumph Motor Company (part of British Leyland) in 1977 in very limited numbers: probably no more than 61 in total. It used the 127\xa0bhp, 16-valve, 2-litre version of the Triumph slant-four engine from the Triumph Dolomite Sprint, a highly tuned version of which, "rated at 225\xa0bhp at 8000\xa0rpm" by 1977, was used in the Group 4 TR7 cars of the BL works rally team, from 1976 until 1978. This was instead of the TR7 base model\'s 105\xa0bhp, 8-valve, 2-litre version of the same basic slant-4 engine. The 16-valve version was originally specified in the Dolomite Sprint at 135\xa0bhp, and carefully assembled, standard engines had been known to give a sustained 150\xa0bhp on the factory test bed.\n', 'The Triumph TR6 (1968–76) is a sports car built by British Triumph Motor Company between 1968 and 1976. It was the best-seller of the TR range when production ended, a record subsequently surpassed by the TR7. Of the 91,850 TR6s produced, 83,480 were exported; only 8,370 were sold in the UK.\n', 'Because of proposed US legislation on roll-over protection at the time of its launch, the TR7 was not initially available as a convertible. In early 1979, Triumph belatedly introduced a convertible version, called the TR7 Drophead Coupé (DHC), which first went on sale in the US (the original hardtop model being known as the Fixedhead Coupé, or FHC). A small number of pre-production cars were manufactured at Speke in 1978, soon after the pre-production TR7 V8 (later designated TR8) and TR7 Sprint cars. The British market received it in early 1980. The prototype for the convertible version of the original Harris Mann design came from Michelotti and the engineering to make it work was done by Triumph.\n', "In 1982, a successful relationship with Tom Walkinshaw's TWR team commenced with the XJ-S competing in the European Touring Car Championship, which it won in 1984. In 1985, the TWR XJ-S won the Bathurst 1000 race. In the mid-1980s TWR started designing and preparing Jaguar V12-engined Group C cars for World Sports Prototype Championship races. The team started winning regularly from 1987, and won Le Mans in 1988 and 1990 with the XJR series sports cars. The Jaguar XJR-14 was the last of the XJRs to win, taking the 1991 World Sportscar Championship.\n", "TWR created 'TWR Sport' in 1984 to produce heavily modified versions of the Jaguar XJ-S. Designated XJR-S, the cars benefited from the racing experience in European Touring Cars, featuring improved aerodynamics; uprated suspension and brakes; tuned engine and detail changes. The success of TWR Sport led to the formalising of a joint venture (50/50) in 1988 called 'Jaguar Sport'. Jaguar Sport would initially focus on building tuned versions of Jaguar road cars (the XJR-S coupe and XJR saloon). However, with overwhelming demand to put the concept Jaguar XJ220 into production, it was decided that Jaguar Sport would design and develop the new supercar, for which a new facility was secured at Bloxham, Oxfordshire. Production commenced in 1990 with the final cars delivered in 1993.\n", 'The Triumph TR4 is a sports car produced by the Triumph Motor Company from 1961 to 1965. Code named "Zest" during development, it was the successor to the TR3A. The car was based on the chassis and drivetrain of the previous TR sports cars, but with a modern body designed by Michelotti. As 40,253 cars were built during its production years it proved to be very successful.\n']

question_info.question: During the 1970s which car maker produced the Triumph TR7 and the Jaguar XJS?
passages:
The Triumph TR7 is a sports car which was manufactured from September 1974 to October 1981 by the Specialist Division (latterly the "Jaguar-Rover-Triumph" division) of British Leyland in the United Kingdom. It was initially produced at the Speke, Liverpool factory, moving to Canley, Coventry in 1978 and then finally to the Rover Solihull plant in 1980. The car was launched in the United States in January 1975, with its UK home market debut in May 1976. The UK launch was delayed at least twice because of high demand for the vehicle in the US, with final sales of new TR7s continuing into 1982.
TWR Jaguar cars won the WSCC outright in 1987, 1988 and 1991 and won the prestigious 24 Hours of Le Mans and the 24 Hours of Daytona in 1988 and 1990. The series started in 1985 with XJR-6 (Group 44 used XJR-5 and XJR-7), designed by Tony Southgate, with a chassis built from carbon-fibre and power provided by a highly tuned Jaguar V12 engine. This was followed by XJR-8, which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1987, then XJR-9 which won the WSCC Team's Championship in 1988 and also secured victory at Le Mans the same year, returning in much the same form as the XJR-12 to win Le Mans again in 1990. TWR developed its own engine for the next series of cars, the XJR-10 (for IMSA) and XJR-11 (for WSCC) of 1989 and 1990, a V6 turbo-charged 3.5 litre, which was capable of far more power than the V12 but was less suited to 24 hour racing (hence the XJR-12 being deployed at Le Mans and the 24 hours of Daytona).
The Jaguar XJ-S (later called XJS) is a luxury grand tourer manufactured and marketed by British automobile manufacturer Jaguar from 1975 to 1996, in coupé, fixed-profile and full convertible body styles. There were three distinct iterations, with a final production total of 115,413 units over 20 years and seven months.
In November 1944 what was left of the Triumph Motor Company and the Triumph trade name were bought by the Standard Motor Company and a subsidiary "Triumph Motor Company (1945) Limited" was formed with production transferred to Standard's factory at Canley, on the outskirts of Coventry. Triumph's new owners had been supplying engines to Jaguar and its predecessor company since 1938. After an argument between Standard-Triumph Managing Director, Sir John Black, and William Lyons, the creator and owner of Jaguar, Black's objective in acquiring the rights to the name and the remnants of the bankrupt Triumph business was to build a car to compete with the soon to be launched post-war Jaguars.
The Triumph TR7 Sprint version of the Triumph TR7 sports car was produced by the Triumph Motor Company (part of British Leyland) in 1977 in very limited numbers: probably no more than 61 in total. It used the 127 bhp, 16-valve, 2-litre version of the Triumph slant-four engine from the Triumph Dolomite Sprint, a highly tuned version of which, "rated at 225 bhp at 8000 rpm" by 1977, was used in the Group 4 TR7 cars of the BL works rally team, from 1976 until 1978. This was instead of the TR7 base model's 105 bhp, 8-valve, 2-litre version of the same basic slant-4 engine. The 16-valve version was originally specified in the Dolomite Sprint at 135 bhp, and carefully assembled, standard engines had been known to give a sustained 150 bhp on the factory test bed.
The Triumph TR6 (1968–76) is a sports car built by British Triumph Motor Company between 1968 and 1976. It was the best-seller of the TR range when production ended, a record subsequently surpassed by the TR7. Of the 91,850 TR6s produced, 83,480 were exported; only 8,370 were sold in the UK.
Because of proposed US legislation on roll-over protection at the time of its launch, the TR7 was not initially available as a convertible. In early 1979, Triumph belatedly introduced a convertible version, called the TR7 Drophead Coupé (DHC), which first went on sale in the US (the original hardtop model being known as the Fixedhead Coupé, or FHC). A small number of pre-production cars were manufactured at Speke in 1978, soon after the pre-production TR7 V8 (later designated TR8) and TR7 Sprint cars. The British market received it in early 1980. The prototype for the convertible version of the original Harris Mann design came from Michelotti and the engineering to make it work was done by Triumph.
In 1982, a successful relationship with Tom Walkinshaw's TWR team commenced with the XJ-S competing in the European Touring Car Championship, which it won in 1984. In 1985, the TWR XJ-S won the Bathurst 1000 race. In the mid-1980s TWR started designing and preparing Jaguar V12-engined Group C cars for World Sports Prototype Championship races. The team started winning regularly from 1987, and won Le Mans in 1988 and 1990 with the XJR series sports cars. The Jaguar XJR-14 was the last of the XJRs to win, taking the 1991 World Sportscar Championship.
TWR created 'TWR Sport' in 1984 to produce heavily modified versions of the Jaguar XJ-S. Designated XJR-S, the cars benefited from the racing experience in European Touring Cars, featuring improved aerodynamics; uprated suspension and brakes; tuned engine and detail changes. The success of TWR Sport led to the formalising of a joint venture (50/50) in 1988 called 'Jaguar Sport'. Jaguar Sport would initially focus on building tuned versions of Jaguar road cars (the XJR-S coupe and XJR saloon). However, with overwhelming demand to put the concept Jaguar XJ220 into production, it was decided that Jaguar Sport would design and develop the new supercar, for which a new facility was secured at Bloxham, Oxfordshire. Production commenced in 1990 with the final cars delivered in 1993.
The Triumph TR4 is a sports car produced by the Triumph Motor Company from 1961 to 1965. Code named "Zest" during development, it was the successor to the TR3A. The car was based on the chassis and drivetrain of the previous TR sports cars, but with a modern body designed by Michelotti. As 40,253 cars were built during its production years it proved to be very successful.
